X.T: Send Gitlab CI reports & artifacts via e-mail
X.ST: Most users migrating from Jenkins to Gitlab CI are looking for a way to send emails with the reports when a test fails. While Gitlab CI can notify you that a job has failed (or was successful) it will not attach any files or reports to that email.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using Mailgun to send emails from a GitLab pipeline.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The subtitle says it all.

X.ST: We’re taking a look at two commonly-used security tools and detailing how they can help secure your projects.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short presentation of SCA and SAST, and what is available in GitHub.

X.T: Unboxing fork improvements
X.ST: We’re always trying to improve the GitHub developer experience in meaningful ways, and we love learning from our customers. In the last several months we released several new fork capabilities, and we’re publishing revised fork documentation that gives more details with clearer explanations to make fork concepts easier to understand.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A list of the latest improvements done to simplify forks.

X.T: Attacking the Software Supply Chain with a Simple Rename

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A new way to hijack a repository of a renamed user has been found.

X.T: Why and how GitHub encrypts sensitive database columns using ActiveRecord::Encryption
X.ST: You may know that GitHub encrypts your source code at rest, but you may not have known that we encrypt sensitive database columns as well. Read about our column encryption strategy and our decision to adopt the Rails column encryption standard.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Cybersecurity spotlight on bug bounty researcher @ahacker1

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short interview of a bug bounty hunter.

X.T: The power of GitHub in the palm of your hand
X.ST: GitHub Mobile helps keep work going while you're going. Untether yourself from your office.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: GitHub is beta testing its mobile app.

X.T: Exciting new GitHub features powering machine learning

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Improved diff display for Jupyter Notebooks and executing ML Notebook in Codespaces.

X.T: An enterprise account is coming to all Enterprise customers
X.ST: Administrators, or enterprise owners, have the increased responsibility of managing their account and keeping it secure. We are excited to introduce what is new with enterprise accounts and what is coming soon.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: All enterprise customers who pay will get access to an enterprise account.

X.T: New npm features for secure publishing and safe consumption
X.ST: Now you can create tokens with fine-grained permissions for automating your publishing and organization management workflows. And a new code explorer allows you to view content of a package directly in the npm portal.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some npmjs.com improvements: tokens with a finer granularity, a code explorer, and enforging 2FA for the maintainers of the most popular packages.

X.T: Experiment: The hidden costs of waiting on slow build times
X.ST: How much does it really cost to buy more powerful cloud compute resources for development work? A lot less than you think.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author tries to evaluate the cost of paying a more powerful server vs. the salary of the developpers, but her model is too simplistic to be a good argument, despite the fact that her conclusion is concensual.

X.T: Leaked a secret? Check your GitHub alerts…for free
X.ST: GitHub now allows you to track any leaked secrets in your public repository, for free. With secret scanning alerts, you can track and action on leaked secrets directly within GitHub.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Secret scanning is now available for public repositories.
